entries.title: Illinois hires former Montana coach Bobby Hauck as defensive coordinator
entries.summary: <p>CHAMPAIGN — Former Montana coach Bobby Hauck has ended his brief retirement to become defensive coordinator at Illinois.</p><p>Fighting Illini coach Bret Bielema announced the hiring Monday to replace Aaron Henry, who left to be co-defensive coordinator at Notre Dame.</p><p>Hauck retired last Wednesday, saying he didn't enjoy his job anymore because of the changes in college football in recent years.</p><p>"I want to enjoy my career and my job, and a lot of the head coach stuff in current-day Division I college football is not enjoyable," Hauck said last week.</p><p>The 61-year-old Hauck is the Big Sky Conference's all-time wins leader with a 151-43 record. He led the Grizzlies to four national championship games in 13 playoff appearances over 14 seasons. Montana was 13-2 and reached the national semifinals last season.</p><p>Hauk led UNLV from 2010 to 2014 and had a 15-49 record. He has been an assistant at San Diego State, Washington, Colorado, Northern Arizona, UCLA and Montana.</p><p>"Since meeting coach Hauck early on in my head coaching career, I have had tremendous respect for who he is, what he stands for, and the program he has built," Bielema said.</p><p>Illinois was 9-4 last season, finishing just outside of the AP Top 25.<br></p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: White Sox bring back Erick Fedde to compete for spot in rotation
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="_blank" ><u>White Sox</u></a> brought back a familiar face to fight for a spot in their starting rotation Monday on the eve of pitchers’ and catchers' official report date for spring training, agreeing to a one-year deal with <b>Erick Fedde</b> pending a physical, a source confirmed.</p><p>Fedde will look to rediscover the serviceable form he provided in 2024 after general manager <b>Chris Getz</b> first snagged him from South Korea’s KBO League, going 7-4 with a 3.11 ERA in 21 starts as a rare bright spot on a squad that ended up losing a modern-era-record 121 games.</p><p>The right-hander, who turns 33 this month, led that team with 4.6 wins above replacement, per Baseball Reference, despite being dealt to St. Louis at that year’s trade deadline.</p><p>Getz declined to comment on the deal, which wasn’t official when he spoke to reporters outside the team’s Arizona training complex, but he noted Fedde “had a lot of success here not too long ago.”</p><p>Things went south for Fedde last year during stints with the Cardinals, Braves and Brewers, as he posted an overall record of 4-13 with a 5.49 ERA across 24 starts and 8 relief appearances. His fastball tops out around 93 mph along with a sinker, cutter, sweeper and change.</p><p>While he turned it around late last season out of the bullpen for Milwaukee, holding hatters to a .186 average, Fedde figures to be back in the starting mix for manager <b>Will Venable</b> and first-year pitching coach <b>Zach Bove</b>.</p><p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/01/09/white-sox-to-have-open-competition-for-last-two-rotation-spots" target="_blank" ><u>only names inked</u></a> in the Sox' rotation so far are ‘25 All-Star <b>Shane Smith</b>, <b>Davis Martin</b> and free-agent signing <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/12/09/anthony-kay-regained-his-confidence-overseas-white-sox-hope-he-can-translate-that-success-to-the-majors" target="_blank" ><b><u>Anthony Kay</u></b></a>.</p><p>The Sox previously added <b>Sean Newcomb</b> to compete for a spot with <b>Jonathan Cannon</b> and <b>Sean Burke</b>, while second-year right-handers <b>Grant Taylor</b> and <b>Mike Vasil </b>look to make their cases for the rotation as well after impressive rookie years mostly out of the bullpen. Newcomers <b>Chris Murphy</b>, <b>Jedixson Paez</b> and <b>David Sandlin</b> could be in the fray, too.</p><p>“We'll sit down with each guy in the beginning of camp, we'll start doing it tomorrow, and talk about what we're aiming to accomplish this camp and the possibilities that might come out of it,” Getz said.</p><p>Joel Sherman of the New York Post first reported Fedde's signing.</p><p><b>Early arrivals</b></p><p>The Sox’ first full-squad workout isn’t until Sunday, but Japanese phenom <b>Munetaka Murakami </b>was among players getting some early work in at Camelback Ranch.</p><p>His session in the batting cage drew about a dozen members of the Japanese baseball press corps and plenty of Sox fans eager for a first look at the slugging first baseman.</p><p>Murakami is a household name overseas, where he was a two-time MVP for the Tokyo Yakult Swallows, and a hero for Japan’s World Baseball Classic-winning squad in 2023 before signing <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/12/22/we-found-our-guy-white-sox-rebuild-taking-shape-after-signing-munetaka-murakami" target="_blank" ><u>a two-year, $34 million deal with the Sox</u></a>.</p><p>But Sox staffers apparently are still getting used to his name. He arrived to find his name misspelled above his locker Sunday as “Munetaki.”</p><p>Murakami posted a photo of the misnomer to his Instagram with thinking-face and tongue-out emojis.</p><p>“He made a post about it in jest,” Getz said. “We certainly are getting that fixed if we haven't already.”</p><p>Murakami is training with the Sox for the next two weeks before rejoining Team Japan for the WBC.</p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-4a0005" entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: Bulls drop fifth straight as the negativity still hovers over franchise
entries.summary: <p>NEW YORK – Billy Donovan is preparing for the inevitable.</p><p>The Bulls coach doesn’t know when, doesn’t know where, but he knows it’s coming. After all, most of the new additions to the roster weren’t playing these kinds of minutes, and they definitely weren’t playing at this pace.</p><p>“I do think this group is going to hit the wall,” Donovan said. “Coming out of the All-Star Break, what those last 27 games are going to look like for us physically is going to be a big factor.”</p><p>That’s why he’s trying to control workload as well as get as many players in the gym between games for conditioning, doing his best to soften how hard that wall hits back.</p><p>What Donovan can’t control? The negativity surrounding the organization – specifically the front office – in the aftermath of the trade deadline.</p><p>Thanks to the 123-115 loss to the Nets on Monday, the Bulls have lost five straight games – three since the deadline. All fine and good, as they have obviously picked a “stage” of the soft tank. What the Bulls are being ripped on for is not the players they traded, as much as why they waited so long to move a few of them and the return they received.</p><p>While Donovan is not on social media and pretty deaf to the outside noise, he doesn’t exist under a rock. He knows what’s being said and even discussed it with his locker room.</p><p>“Are they coming into the situation going, ‘OK, what are we trying to do here?’ “ Donovan said. “If that (negative) stuff is out there, and I’ve tried to talk to them about what our focus is and what our direction needs to be inside our team. There are guys with expiring contracts, some guys that want to play, so we gotta help each other, go out there and compete. All that kind of stuff is important, so I’ve tried to redirect their focus onto that. ‘What do we got to do to get better as a team?’</p><p>“I can see people on the outside, ‘Are they really trying to win? What’s with this group because who is going to be back, who isn’t going to be back. Maybe these guys are auditioning, they really don’t care.’ I still think inside that locker room these guys are professionals, and they don’t want to come in every day, work, try and buy in and it’s like, ‘OK, we’re just going to experiment with all this stuff.’ “</p><p>Besides, there’s enough experimenting going on from Donovan, as the coach is just trying to mix and match different lineup looks and see what works.</p><p>The starting group remained the same, as Donovan went with Guerschon Yabusele, Isaac Okoro, Matas Buzelis, Anfernee Simons and Jaden Ivey, while Nick Richards, Collin Sexton and Rob Dillingham saw minutes off the bench.</p><p>With the Bulls down six with 2:55 left in the game, however, it was Sexton, Simons, Okoro, Buzelis and Richards for closing time. It did not go well, as the group actually lost ground with the defensive breakdowns continuing.</p><p>By the time the final horn sounded, what most summed up the latest loss was the Bulls being led in rebounds by the 6-foot-2 Dillingham. He had a career-high seven.</p><p>Just the latest example of how small this group is, as well as how they are trying to figure it all out on the fly.</p><p>“We’re going through it,” Ivey said of the growing pains after the latest loss. “Going through it together. That’s how you learn, that’s how you grow. That’s how you make each other better and figure ways to win the game and affect the game, communicating and talking, and being there for one another.</p><p>“As we continue to progress in games, we’ll understand that and make adjustments on that.”</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: Bulls players dealing with the aftermath of the deadline roster purge
entries.summary: <p>NEW YORK — The players shipped out last week in the Bulls’ trade-deadline purge certainly weren’t the only ones affected, as the locker room changed almost overnight.</p><p>Coach <b>Billy Donovan</b> admitted being “a little sensitive” to the emotions that second-year forward <b>Matas Buzelis</b> was going through after losing a handful of veteran mentors who had helped him in his first year-plus in the NBA.</p><p>“It’s the first time he’s gone through it,” Donovan said. “I talked to him [over the weekend] about that, and I think he was still digesting that, quite honestly. Last year after the trade deadline, you had the All-Star break, the rest of that year, the whole summer where you’re with these guys. I think he got a taste of ‘This is a business.’ . . . [But] as much as he understands the business side of it, it’s a little bit different for him. That speaks to the relationship he had with all those guys.”</p><p>Buzelis downplayed his emotions.</p><p>“It’s tough after first hearing [the news], but I’m a guy that lives in the present, and unfortunately that happened to our team,” he said. “I wish all the best for those guys that moved forward, and that’s just what it is. You have to focus on the next day. Fortunately, I’ve had to wipe it out of my memory, and that’s just how I was trained when I was younger.”</p><p>The Bulls were one of the busiest teams at the deadline, waiving guard <b>Jevon Carter</b> and trading center <b>Nikola Vucevic</b> (Celtics), guard <b>Coby White</b> (Hornets), guard <b>Ayo Dosunmu </b>and forward <b>Julian Phillips </b>(Timberwolves), guard/forward <b>Kevin Huerter</b> (Pistons) and guard/forward <b>Dalen Terry</b> (Knicks, later to Pelicans, who waived him).</p><p>Donovan admitted to feelings of his own once the dust settled.</p><p>“First guy I [would] see when I walk in [the locker room] is [Vucevic],” Donovan said. “And he’s not there.”</p><p><b>Breaking their way?</b></p><p>The Bulls still are without guards <b>Josh Giddey</b> and <b>Tre Jones</b> (injured left hamstrings) and bigs <b>Zach Collins </b>(toe) and <b>Jalen Smith</b> (right calf).</p><p>There’s a good chance, though, that Giddey and Jones will be back soon after the All-Star break. Donovan said both have been playing three-on-three ball and running in full. The Bulls are being extra cautious with them, which is easier since they now have a bunch of new guards who need minutes as part of the evaluation process.</p><p>The news wasn’t as good for the bigs. Collins has spent time on an anti-gravity treadmill but is still in a walking boot. Smith is still dealing with tightness in the calf.</p><p><b>More leeway for the new guy</b></p><p>Donovan has used tough love with Buzelis but seems to be leaning toward a more hands-off coaching approach with newly acquired guard <b>Rob Dillingham</b>, the No. 8 overall pick by the Spurs in 2024.</p><p>Dillingham said he’s being allowed to play through mistakes.</p><p>“It’s really about making it a gritty game, and if you mess up, you mess up, but just play fast,” Dillingham said of the message from Donovan. “That’s what Coach wants, and he reassured me of that for sure.”<br></p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: GM Chris Getz not playing numbers game as White Sox look to stave off another 100-loss season
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="_blank" >White Sox</a> general manager Chris Getz is done talking about triple-digit-loss seasons.</p><p>At least, he really would like to be.</p><p>The Sox have crossed the dreaded century mark three times under his watch, though most of the ugliness of 2023 landed on former GM Rick Hahn before Getz replaced him late in the season.</p><p>The Sox lost 101 games that season, took 20 steps backward to their historically bad 121-loss season in 2024, then weathered a relatively cheery 102 defeats last season.</p><p>The 2025 vibes were as good as could be expected for a team that won only a little more than an average of two games per week. That was because of the legitimate young talent Getz & Co. started to stack, including a possible superstar in shortstop Colson Montgomery and perhaps the best young catching tandem in baseball in Kyle Teel and Edgar Quero.</p><p>Now the Sox even have shelled out some free-agent cash for slugging Japanese wunderkind <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/12/22/we-found-our-guy-white-sox-rebuild-taking-shape-after-signing-munetaka-murakami" target="_blank" ><u>Munetaka Murakami</u></a>, but they also have shed the tantalizing ‘‘boom’’ potential of center fielder <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/01/21/white-sox-plan-to-be-very-active-in-upgrading-roster-after-trading-center-fielder-luis-robert-jr" target="_blank" ><u>Luis Robert Jr.</u></a> after too many frustrating seasons of watching him go bust. And question marks stretch from the outfield into a young starting rotation.</p><p>So while things might be getting better on paper, Getz isn’t ready to guarantee the Sox will earn at least 63 victories this season to stave off one of the worst four-season stretches in MLB history.</p><p>‘‘We know we are going to make meaningful strides in the right direction,’’ Getz said Monday as players, coaches and staffers trickled into Camelback Ranch the day before pitchers and catchers officially report for spring training. ‘‘That shows up in a lot of different ways.</p><p>‘‘Obviously, winning baseball games at the major-league level is why we come here, why we show up. We are building. We’ve accumulated a lot of talent. We have players pushing toward the major leagues. We have players more experienced at the major-league level. We know that’s going to lead to more success. We are focused on what’s in front of us on that particular day. Regardless of what happens on that day, we will have that same mindset on the following day.’’</p><p>It wasn’t exactly an oversell on the eve of spring training, where hope springs eternal.</p><p>As for the Sox’ chances of potentially surprising rivals in the American League Central, Getz only would say: ‘‘We feel like we can go out there and compete on a regular basis. We showed that in the second half [of last season], regardless of who we were playing against. We won some really good series against some good ballclubs. We hope to take that same mindset and approach into this year. There’s no reason why we can’t get off to a really good start and see where the year takes us.’’</p><p>Getz said he’s especially excited to watch the continued development of 23-year-old flame-thrower Grant Taylor and 25-year-old Swiss Army man Mike Vasil, both of whom showed impressive flashes in relief last season but are pushing for shots as starters.</p><p>Getz also pointed to right-hander Shane Smith building on <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2025/09/28/shane-smith-nationals-white-sox-2025-102-losses" target="_blank" >his All-Star rookie campaign</a>, plus left-handed power arms Hagen Smith and Noah Schultz likely jumping to the majors at some point.</p><p>But he said the season is also about building on ‘‘a fair amount of momentum’’ that was nonexistent when he took the reins, thanks to players who have grown up together through the Sox’ system.</p><p>‘‘They love being around each other,’’ Getz said. ‘‘They love playing together. They’re learning how to win.’’</p><p>It all might sound familiar to Sox fans still reeling from another rebuild that never built to much of anything with players such as Robert, Eloy Jimenez and Yoan Moncada.</p><p>But Getz said second-year manager Will Venable has this younger crew ‘‘focused to start at ground zero’’ for a stronger foundation.</p><p>‘‘We feel really good about where we’re at,’’ he said. ‘‘The room is excited; they’re hungry. But we’ve got to go out and play good baseball, and that’s why we’re out here at spring training — to really set the stage for that.’’</p>
entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: With Bears and others chasing, Seahawks already intent on staying ‘on the forefront’
entries.summary: <p>SAN FRANCISCO — It’s easy for an NFL team, especially during a rebuild, to become so engrossed in getting itself on track that it forgets the rest of the league is trying to do the same.</p><p>Even the Seahawks, the morning after <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/08/super-bowl-lx-seahawks-lead-patriots-9-0-at-halftime-as-defenses-dominate" >winning Super Bowl LX</a> against the Patriots, are fixed on improving for next season as everyone takes aim at them. They won’t just sit and wait for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >the Bears</a> and others to catch up. Instead, they’re looking to widen the gap.</p><p>“We use the term ‘chasing edges’ here in Seattle,” coach Mike Macdonald said Monday. “You have to live like that. . . . We want to be on the forefront of things. We know that we’re Target No. 1 now.”</p><p>The Seahawks quietly dominated in the regular season, going 14-3 in the extremely tough NFC West and leading the NFL with a plus-191 scoring differential. The Bears, by comparison, were a plus-26.</p><p>With the No. 1 scoring defense, the Seahawks steamrolled the 49ers and outlasted the Rams to reach the Super Bowl, then blanketed the Patriots for a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/08/super-bowl-lx-seahawks-mvp-kenneth-walker-iii-powers-offense-to-win-super-bowl-mvp" >29-13 win at Levi’s Stadium</a> for the second championship in franchise history. They held the Patriots scoreless until early in the fourth quarter, and most or all of that defense will be back next season.</p><p>The numbers were scary for any team that assumes it’ll be able to run its offense normally against the Seahawks next season. They sacked Patriots quarterback Drake Maye six times for a net loss of 53 yards and held him to a 79.1 passer rating after he led the NFL with a 113.5 during the regular season. Running backs TreVeyon Henderson and Rhamondre Stevenson combined to average 96.7 rushing yards per game during the regular season but totaled just 42 on Sunday. Wide receiver Stefon Diggs had a pedestrian 37 yards on three catches.</p><p>The Patriots’ offense was second in the NFL at 28.8 points per game, so the challenge ahead won’t be any less daunting for the Bears (ninth, 25.9). An 11-6 record with an exit in the divisional round of the playoffs won’t be celebrated again in Chicago. For them to get a firm grasp on what they’ll need to do next season to go all the way — and what’s the point of enduring a rebuild if the goal isn’t a championship? — they’ll need a clear view of what the Seahawks have.</p><p>What they have is an exceptional defense and a good offense, a combination that made things easier for quarterback Sam Darnold, who took full advantage this season. No one considers Darnold a superstar, and he played unremarkably Sunday, but he wasn’t merely along for the ride, finishing the regular season in the top 11 in passer rating, yardage and touchdown passes.</p><p>That said, the Seahawks went against the trend, proving defense can still win. Macdonald, just 38, is the first defensive-minded head coach to capture a title since Bill Belichick seven years ago and is believed to be the first coach to win a Super Bowl as his team’s defensive play-caller. Essentially, he’s the defensive version of what the Bears believe they found in coach Ben Johnson.</p><p>With a visit to Seattle coming up on the schedule next season, Johnson and quarterback Caleb Williams will get their shot at the Seahawks’ defense — perhaps as early as the season opener in September. Rams coach Sean McVay and quarterback Matthew Stafford already have been seething for weeks in anticipation of going after the Seahawks again. The Lions are loaded. The Cowboys and 49ers can put up points with the best of them. The NFC is full of explosive offenses that will spend the offseason innovating, analyzing and upgrading to give themselves a chance to take down the defending champs.</p><p>“It’s really going to be our mentality for us to keep pushing the envelope with our personnel and where we can take things,” Macdonald said. “There’s going to be times where teams get a bead on us and we’re going to have to move and shake, and that’s happened several times this season. That’s just how we operate.”</p><p>The bright spot for the Bears is that this conversation is much different than the one they usually have this time of year. For years, the Super Bowl was a slap of reality for them, leaving no doubt about how lost they were compared to champions such as the Eagles, Chiefs and Rams. This time, after a season in which they asserted themselves as a real threat in the NFC, they’re looking at how close they might be to catching the Seahawks, not how far away.</p><bsp-list-loadmore entries.title: Illinois lawmakers announce plan to close school funding gap
entries.summary: <p>A plan to significantly boost funding for public education in Illinois has been introduced to both houses of the state Legislature as some lawmakers aim to eventually tax millionaires and digital advertisement to help bridge billions needed to finance schools.</p><p>Standing among teachers, members of the Chicago Teacher’s Union and others in the education field, sponsors state Sen. Graciela Guzmán, D-Chicago, and state Rep. Will Davis, D-Hazel Crest, announced on Monday the introduction of their <a class="Link" href="https://www.ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus/FullText?GAID=18&DocNum=5409&DocTypeID=HB&LegId=0&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >respective bills</a> to fund Illinois schools to match the requirements of a nearly decade-old benchmark the General Assembly set for itself.</p><p>In 2017, lawmakers passed the evidence-based funding formula, which allocates funds to schools based on their individual needs and demographics. With it came the promise to fund each school’s needs by at least 90% by 2027, as well as “mandated categoricals” — such as transportation for students with disabilities and aspects of special education — that schools are required to fund via state and federal law.</p><p>The new proposals, introduced last week, would fulfill the requirement — bridging a $5 billion gap that increased for the second year in a row last year, increasing $573 million — while fully funding the “mandated categoricals.”</p><p>“The evidence-based formula was designed to correct generations of disinvestment,” said Guzmán, a former CTU organizer. “But it only works if it's actually funded. ... This bill is about fulfilling our promise that Illinois should meet the needs of our students, families and communities."</p><p>The proposals don't directly hike taxes, but Guzmán pointed to other proposals that would tax millionaires and digital advertising as a revenue stream for schools.</p><p>Davis also pointed to Gov. JB Pritzker's announcement of a plan to pay off state pensions years earlier than previously promised, saying education should be put on the same level as pensions when it comes to state priorities.</p><p>“He’s prioritizing big sums of money in other areas,” Davis said about Pritzker. “The administration has a comfort level of where we’re at right now, but when we see those press releases, he’s prioritizing big sums of money into a lot of other areas. … In my conversations, they have a comfort level. We need to move out of that comfort zone.”</p><p>Ralph Martire, executive director at the Center for Tax and Budget Accountability and a co-author of the original evidence based funding formula legislation, said a millionaire’s tax could be tricky, as it would likely require a state constitutional amendment to override Illinois’ restrictions on such a measure.</p><p>He suggested increasing the state income tax while adding a low income credit as a way to generate what he says is potentially more than $3 billion in revenue left on the table, while instituting a more progressive tax structure with less legal headwinds. Expanding the state’s “narrow” sales tax alongside that, mirroring neighbors Iowa or Wisconsin, could net another couple billion — enough to cover the costs.</p><p></p><p>“I think they’re trying to put pressure on the General Assembly and governor to do what the state said it would do,” Martire said. “But to live up to its statutory obligations, it certainly needs more revenue.”</p><div data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>State Sen. Graciela Guzmán discusses education funding Monday at the Bilandic Building in the Loop.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p> Pritzker didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. Guzmán and Davis said they have yet to speak with the governor, but they have been in touch with members of his team.</p><p>Last year, CPS was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/08/04/chicago-public-schools-budget-deficit" target="_blank" ><u>one of more than 300 underfunded districts</u></a> in the state getting a smaller percentage of what it needs compared to the prior year.</p><p>At the current rate, it will <a class="Link" href="https://www.ctbaonline.org/reports/fully-funding-evidenced-based-formula-volume-xi" target="_blank" ><u>take until at least 2037</u></a> to reach the level mandated by the original bill, closing a $3.3 billion gap, according to the Center on Tax and Budget Accountability. Now Guzman and Davis say that’s been pushed to 2039. On top of that, mandated categoricals would add another $1.7 billion, according to Martire.</p><p>And the gap is widening. The state pointed to a significant decrease in revenue from a state tax on corporations, as well as “rising education costs” like inflation and cost-of-living raises, as to why schools statewide lost an average of half a percent toward adequacy, down to 76.6%; CPS saw a six-point drop to 73%.<br></p>

entries.title: Former prospect sues White Sox, claiming COVID-19 vaccination ended his career
entries.summary: <p>A former <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="_blank" >White Sox</a> pitching prospect is suing the team, claiming he was pushed into taking a COVID-19 vaccination in 2021 that resulted in severe allergic reactions that eventually derailed his career.</p><p>Isaiah Carranza, a 12th-round draft pick of the Sox in 2018, alleges team officials warned him he would be ‘‘blacklisted’’ if he didn’t get two doses of the vaccine, meaning they wouldn’t release him from his contract for opportunities with other clubs even though had ‘‘no prospects of moving up’’ with the Sox.</p><p>Carranza got the Pfizer vaccine and soon began suffering ‘‘extreme dizziness, nausea, near-fainting and wildly fluctuating heart rate’’ that the team chalked up to dehydration, anxiety and ‘‘rookie nerves,’’ attorneys for Carranza claimed in his federal lawsuit, which was filed in December in Chicago.</p><p>Numerous studies have shown that COVID-19 vaccinations are highly effective at preventing severe cases of the respiratory disease and that severe allergic reactions are exceedingly rare. The Illinois Department of Public Health recommends the vaccine <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2025/09/23/illinois-covid-19-vaccine-adults-cdc-children" target="_blank" >for nearly all people</a> 6 months or older as a means of minimizing the severity of infections.</p><p>MLB encouraged players to get vaccinated but did not mandate it when the game returned early in the pandemic.</p><p>Carranza later was diagnosed with a nervous-system disorder that his lawyers tie to the vaccine. He never advanced beyond the Sox’ High-A affiliate and hasn’t appeared in a minor-league game since 2022.</p><p>Carranza’s estimated future medical expenses are more than $557,000, his lawyers say. A Sox spokesman declined to comment on the active litigation.</p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-show-loadmore="true" ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-4a0005" name="list-4a0005"></a><div class="PageList-header" > <div class="PageList-header-title-wrap" > <div class="PageList-header-title"> <a class="" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" target="{borderColor=#dfdfdf, pageNumber=1, inverseColors=false, pullQuoteIcon=[{image=null, narrowImage=null, _template=/image/Image.hbs, alt=null}], footerBgColor=#000000, bodyFont=font-3, showListNumbers=false, imagePositionHorizontal=null, rteBodyFont=font-3, headerBottomBorderColor=#111010, subTitle=null, pageCount=2420, stickyHeader=true, listTitleColor=#000000, tableCellBorderColor=#ccd1d5, relatedListFont=font-1, hideAuthors=true, tertiaryTextColor=#6c6c6c, buttonHoverTextColor=#ffffff, items=[{timestamp=1770682260000, type=Image, _styledTemplate=null, imageAlignment=null, categoryUrl=https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox, description=[{items=[Fedde was a rare bright spot on the Sox’ dismal 2024 squad, but he struggled last season. ]}], isFeatured=false, anchorId=promo-150000, target=null, authors=[{name=[{items=[Mitchell Armentrout]}], jobTitle=[{items=[Reporter/assistant editor]}], media=[{alt=Mitchell Armentrout, ampLink=null, _styledTemplate=null, _template=/image/Image.hbs, image={src=https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/fc/ce/f20d6ee54780a793233d9b8dc7ef/armentrout-01.jpg, width=5053, height=3370}, narrowImage={src=https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/fc/ce/f20d6ee54780a793233d9b8dc7ef/armentrout-01.jpg, width=5053, height=3370}}], ampLink=null, _styledTemplate=null, _template=/author/byline/AuthorByline.hbs, bio=[{items=[Mitchell Armentrout is a staff reporter covering government and politics from Chicago to Springfield, focusing on the expansion of gambling across Illinois as well as the Chicago Bears’ quest for a new stadium. entries.title: Horoscope for Tuesday, February 10, 2026
entries.summary: <h2>Moon Alert</h2> <p>After 1:45 a.m., there are no restrictions to shopping or important decisions today. The moon is in Sagittarius.</p><h2>Aries (March 21-April 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today you're best off if you coordinate your needs with the needs of others and work in conjunction with them. Be open to this. Meanwhile, for the next three weeks, opportunities for secret love affairs and flirtations are everywhere.</p><h2>Taurus (April 20-May 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Your ambition is aroused! Don't hesitate to go after what you want and demand the advantage. Discussions with friends and groups, especially with younger people, will be positive because your schmooze skills are tops. People are attracted to you today.</p><h2>Gemini (May 21-June 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> No matter what you do for a living, in the next three weeks, people will ask for your advice on how to make something look better. Your ability to charm bosses and VIPs will be excellent. In fact, you'll be so charming that some of you will begin a romance with a boss.</p><h2>Cancer (June 21-July 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Try to get out of town in the next three weeks because your desire to travel for pleasure will be strong. If you can't travel, be a tourist in your own city. Visit galleries, university campuses, parks, architectural buildings and beautiful stores. Fill your cup.</p><h2>Leo (July 23-Aug. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Money and favors from others can come to you today, while you want the freedom to do your own thing and enjoy yourself. Meet friends. Check out sports and the arts. Relax. In the next three weeks, romance will be passionate and special.</p><h2>Virgo (Aug. 23-Sept. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> For the next three weeks, your relationships with partners, spouses and close friends will be sensitive, meaningful and affectionate. It will be the perfect time to bury the hatchet or build bridges. A casual relationship might become more committed. You're also working hard.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> If you're involved in competitive sports or the performing arts, you're on your game. Find outlets for your creative talents. Today you want to talk to someone, which means you need to find someone who will listen and appreciate what you have to say. A work-related romance might begin.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Romance will be affectionate, meaningful and idealistic in the next three weeks. This same energy can also ignite your creative talents, which is good news for artists. Meanwhile, deal with increased chaos on the home front. Pull your act together.</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You might feel more emotional than usual today because the moon is in your sign. However, this also means that your luck is slightly better than everyone else's. Enjoy entertaining at home. You might redecorate or do something to make where you live more attractive.</p><h2>Capricorn (Dec. 22-Jan. 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> For various reasons (according to the details of your life), you will enjoy the beauty of your daily surroundings in the next several weeks. What a blessing! Discussions with others will be meaningful. Act on your moneymaking ideas. Research might pay off today.</p><h2>Aquarius (Jan. 20-Feb. 18)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You have lots of energy with both the sun and fiery Mars in your sign, which is why you need to find an outlet to channel this drive. Physical exercise is one option. It's also a good day to share your hopes and dreams for the future with a friend. entries.title: Rideshare driver, passenger sickened by hazardous package in Logan Square
entries.summary: <p>A ride share driver and his passenger were sickened after coming in contact with a suspicious package while driving in Logan Square, prompting a hazardous materials incident Monday night. </p><p>Officers responded to their 911 call around 9:55 p.m. in the 2200 block of North Monticello Avenue when the driver and the passenger began feeling unwell after picking up a package in the 3600 block of West Palmer Street, Chicago police said. </p><p>The fire department's hazmat team responded to the scene and the package — which was not described — was recovered from the vehicle, officials said.</p><p>They were taken to Norwegian Hospital where they were in fair condition, police said. </p><p>Area 5 detectives were investigating.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Dear Abby: Man opts to take ex on trip instead of his girlfriend
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My boyfriend of several years, "Guy," often asks me to take a trip with him. I have researched accommodations at the suggested destinations, only to have him say they are too pricey. Thus, we never go anywhere, although he could easily afford it.</p><p>Now his brother (whom I've never met) has suggested a family cruise and suggested that Guy bring along his ex-wife, who is in the early stages of dementia. Guy has been divorced from her for decades. I haven't said anything to him about this, though I am shocked and hurt that when a trip is finally planned, Guy thinks it's fine to take her rather than me. I'd be OK with him not taking either of us, but not with choosing her over me. Am I the crazy one here?</p><p>P.S. Right now, I am dog-sitting for Guy for the second time in a month while he's out of state for a week attending to his ex-wife's legal matters, including her will. — <i>HOME ALONE IN FLORIDA</i></p><p><b>DEAR HOME ALONE:</b> Something definitely seems out of focus in this family picture. Your boyfriend has been divorced from his ex for DECADES. Is his brother oblivious to the fact that you have been Guy's companion for several years? If this is a question of money, it seems to me that a more practical solution than leaving you out would be for Guy to bring you along on the cruise and he and his brother split the cost of including his former wife.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My husband, "Dan," and I are separated. Our children are ages 20 and 22. Dan has just been diagnosed with some type of serious medical issue (likely life-threatening). He has shared the information with our children but refuses to explain to me what is happening. I am not being nosy; I simply believe that I should be aware of what's going on for the sake of our children.</p><p>Our kids are not currently on speaking terms, so they won't discuss the issue with each other. One of them still lives at home and has been diagnosed with autism, ADHD, PTSD and major depressive disorder. They are not doing well and have been hospitalized multiple times over the past five years. They have no friends and no contact with extended family. The only people they interact with are me and their father.</p><p>I feel it is very important to keep me informed so I can offer support and help both of our children deal with whatever is happening. Am I wrong to ask my ex to explain to me what is going on? — <i>IN THE DARK IN VERMONT</i></p><p><b>DEAR IN THE DARK:</b> You are not wrong to ask your estranged husband for that information, in light of the fact that one of the children you share has so many mental health challenges. However, if he refuses, you will have to accept it and deal with your children as best you can with limited information. Believe me, you have my sympathy.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>Abby shares more than 100 of her favorite recipes in two booklets: "Abby's Favorite Recipes" and "More Favorite Recipes by Dear Abby." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $16 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Cookbooklet Set, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: Matters of the heart — Loving case — are part of Black History Month too
entries.summary: <p>We keep Black History Month on one shelf and Valentine’s Day on another. One is supposed to be about pain and struggle. The other about flowers and pastel sugary hearts. Public remembrance of the most important Supreme Court decision about love in American history—<a class="Link" href="https://www.aclu.org/loving" target="_blank" >Loving v. Virginia</a> — waits for June, as if love itself were a summer excursion.</p><p>My life has taught me that matters of the heart belong in Black History Month too. Indeed such a short and bitterly cold month needs the memories of courageous love perhaps more than any other.</p><p>When I was a child in the 1970s, barely a decade after the Court decided Loving, I watched my parents hold hands in public and draw the kind of looks a child never forgets. The law had changed. The reflex had not. We honor Mildred and Richard Loving for their courage, and we should. Yet their victory was not a gift delivered from above. It was the law finally meeting the life people had already been living.</p><p>My maternal grandmother, Mamie Bland, taught me that long before I could name it. Her face was very English. Yet by Virginia law she was unquestionably Black. She carried the stories of our family quietly, without ornament, the way some people carry a Bible. She knew the South lived two lives at once — one written in statutes and another written at kitchen tables. Mamie believed the second life would outlast the first. She was right.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-1c0000" name="module-1c0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Virginia’s history shows that interracial unions were never an exception. They were part of the everyday rhythm of the Commonwealth. After Bacon’s Rebellion — hardly the only time Virginians of different races had made common cause — the ruling class answered with laws meant to keep Black and white people from finding one another again.</p><p>Those walls were rebuilt after Reconstruction and perfected in the <a class="Link" href="https://www.nps.gov/articles/000/racial-integrity-act.htm" target="_blank" >Racial Integrity Act of 1924</a>, the eugenic scheme that forced Virginians into two boxes: white or colored.</p><p>The hypocrisy was written into the fine print. The same statute that criminalized Black-white marriage carved out a special door so white Virginians could continue boasting of descent from Pocahontas and John Rolfe. By law you were 100% white even with one-sixteenth Native ancestry. And by the same law yet one-thirty-second African ancestry made you 100% Black.</p><p>My own family sits inside that ledger. DNA confirmed what Mamie already knew. I descend from the Bland line of Virginia, a family that proudly traced its roots to the Pocahontas-Rolfe union. Yet my great-great-grandfather Edward David Bland was born enslaved because his father Frederick was the son of a Bland planter and an enslaved woman — and Frederick was legally owned by his own half-brother, Richard Yates Bland. That is not a metaphor. It is a document. It is a life passed from one column of a will to another.</p><p>Virginia celebrated a legend while punishing a reality. The colony preferred a story about John Smith rescuing an Indian princess to the recorded marriage between Pocahontas and Rolfe that produced living descendants. Myth was easy to salute. Intimacy was harder to face.</p><p>By the time Mildred Jeter and Richard Loving married in Washington in 1958, generations had already voted with their hearts. Couples crossed county lines, raised children in common-law homes or kept their vows in quiet rooms. The state called those unions unnatural, yet they were as Virginia as the river and the red clay. In 1967 the Supreme Court did not create a new country when it banned laws against interracial marriage in the United States. It recognized the one that had been breathing all along.</p><p>Judge Leon Bazile, who sentenced the Lovings to exile, said God had placed the races on separate continents and never meant them to mix. But the very families who wrote Virginia’s laws had been mixing since the first ships anchored at Jamestown, perhaps even before. There is the truth defined by legislating otherness. And then there is the truth defined by loving one another despite it all</p><p>That is why the story of Loving should be celebrated in February, too. Black history is not only the history of pain and protest. It is also the history of love surviving under threat.</p><p><i>Ben Jealous is a professor of practice at the University of Pennsylvania and former president and CEO of the NAACP.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ef0000" name="module-ef0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Ben Jealous

>Illinois appeal for summer storm disaster relief is denied by Trump administration</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-i/" target="_blank" >Tina Sfondeles</a></h5><h5></h5><p><b>No relief</b>: The Trump administration has officially denied an appeal from the state of Illinois requesting disaster relief funds for summer storms last year that affected 438,000 residents in five Illinois counties.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Gov. JB Pritzker requested authorization of the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s individual assistance for affected counties, as well as disaster loan programs to help Illinoisans after a multiday storm Aug. 16-19 that passed through Boone, Cook, Kane, McHenry and Will counties.</p><p><b>At issue</b>: Trump in October approved major disaster declarations for Alaska, Nebraska, North Dakota and the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe. He touted the same for North Dakota. That led Pritzker to call the denial politically motivated — and to try to appeal the decision. The governor reiterated that point Monday, calling the denial "a Local law enforcement took over crowd control outside the building in October, drawing criticism from demonstrators who accused them of aiding federal agents and using harsh tactics.</p><p><b>Day of arrests</b>: The Rev. Michael Woolf and fellow faith members had set out to provide religious counseling to detainees at the facility the morning of Nov. 14 but were denied entrance. Scuffles broke out with local law enforcement, and 21 people were arrested. The Cook County state’s attorney’s office has now dropped charges in 19 of those cases.</p><p><b>Keeping track</b>: We're tracking every known federal prosecution in Chicago tied to Trump’s immigration blitz. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-b/" target="_blank" >Despite business’ concerns, City Council committee backs parking enforcement by citizens</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-n/" target="_blank" >Fran Spielman</a></h5><p><b>Proposal OKd</b>: The City Council’s Committee on Pedestrian and Traffic Safety approved a newly revised ordinance Monday that would authorize Chicagoans to use their cellphones to provide recorded evidence of bus lane, bike lane and crosswalk parking violations.</p><p><b>Arguments against</b>: Three months ago, concerns raised by business groups stalled the ordinance championed by Committee Chair Daniel La Spata (1st). They argued Chicago was already a maze of protected bike lanes, bump-outs and "changes in parking and turning patterns" that have limited curb access for commercial deliveries and repair vehicles. They also claimed even well-intentioned drivers can struggle to locate legitimate legal loading zones.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-p/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>LET’S HEAR FROM YOU 🗣️</h4><p><b>Should Chicagoans be empowered to use their phones to record parking violations in crosswalks and bus and bike lanes? Cox/Getty</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-jy/" target="_blank" >Bad Bunny taps Chicago conductor to lead surprise orchestra in Super Bowl halftime show</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-jj/" target="_blank" >Kyle MacMillan</a></h5><p>Eagle-eyed Chicago classical music fans spotted a familiar face during Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl halftime show: Giancarlo Guerrero, artistic director and principal conductor of the Grant Park Music Festival.</p><p>Guerrero was spotlighted Sunday among some 700 performers who took part in Bad Bunny’s sprawling performance, which included famed vocalists Ricky Martin and Lady Gaga as well as singers and musicians across a wide range of genres.</p><p>Guerrero, who was named to the Grant Park Music Festival post in 2024 and conducted his first concerts last summer, led a 30-member string orchestra composed of San Francisco-area musicians in the song "Monaco."</p><p>"It has been an absolutely unbelievable, unforgettable, life-changing experience all around," Guerrero told WBEZ and the Sun-Times on Sunday night. "To be part of it, honestly, is one of the greatest joys in my life and something that will stay with me forever."</p><p>In what he called a "beautiful surprise," Guerrero was invited to take part in the show just nine days before it took place.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-jt/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WATCH: GIANCARLO </div> </div> </div></div><hr><p></p><h4>YOUR DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><p>Yesterday, we asked you: <b>Should Chicago be like the suburbs and </b><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-jh/" target="_blank" ><b>install roundabouts</b></a><b> or </b><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyhdiyk-l-jk/" target="_blank" ><b>more traffic circles</b></a><b>?</b></p><p>Here’s some of what you said, edited for space and clarity:</p><p>"Sadly, Chicago drivers are unable to navigate the traffic circles we have now, so adding more would make traffic more dangerous, if that's even possible." — <i>Tom Covell</i></p><p>"Roundabouts could help with some of the multiway intersections like where Broadway meets Bryn Mawr and Ridge [avenues]." — <i>Michael Ross</i></p><p>"I think Chicago would benefit greatly if it implemented more traffic circles near school districts, especially in residential streets ... They can easily be implemented ... Creating a safer environment for city residents!" — <i>Jaime Duque</i></p><p>"I live alongside a roundabout in Lake County ... Before the roundabout, traffic would backup for a 1/4 -1/2 mile while waiting to traverse the intersection during rush hours. Now, traffic of 3-4 cars may accumulate for seconds during the same time spans. The only downside: I have to put my life at risk every day to retrieve my mail from the other side of the road." — <i>Mike Lyne</i></p><p>"Drive the back streets of Rogers Park and get back to us. I'd focus on the streets between Pratt [Boulevard] and Devon [Avenue]. Oof. Oof. Oof." — <i>Suzanne Till</i></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated b</b>y: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. entries.title: CTA Red Line passenger's head stomped during Wrigleyville robbery
entries.summary: <p>Chicago police have released images of a person wanted for beating, robbing and stomping a passenger's head earlier this month in Wrigleyville. </p><p>Around 11:40 a.m. Feb. 1, the victim, a 33-year-old man, was riding Red Line train in the 900 block of West Addison Street when the alleged robber struck them in the face, took their property and stomped on their head, Chicago police said. </p><p>The 33-year-old man declined medical attention and police were still looking for the attacker. </p><p>Authorities encouraged individuals to report suspicious activity and be aware of their surroundings. </p><p>Anyone with information on the incident should call Public Transportation Detectives, (312) 745-4447.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Fuerza Regida, J Balvin, Kali Uchis to headline Sueños 2026
entries.summary: <p>Sueños Music Festival is back in Grant Park on May 23 and 24, with headliners including Kali Uchis and J Balvin joining the previously announced Fuerza Regida.</p><p>Announced Tuesday, the lineup will also include Danny Ocean, Tokischa, Manuel Turizo and Yandel, who will perform a special “Sinfonico” presentation. Festival DJs Fredy Fresco, Dynamiqo and Chicago’s Miriam Paz will also return.</p><p>Sueños has become a fixture during Memorial Day weekend since its launch in 2022, kicking off the city’s music festival season. This year, it’s one of three festivals announced for the holiday weekend.</p><p>Sueños "was created to be an inclusive event with a mission to continue to celebrate and uplift Latin culture and the extraordinary music, people, food and amazing energy that comes along with it," festival organizers said in a news release.</p><p>This is the second Sueños since organizers signed a five-year deal with the Chicago Park District in July 2024 to produce the festival through 2029. Over the last five summers, Sueños has grown into one of the most prominent Latin music festivals in the country, drawing more than 60,000 attendees each day. Last year, the festival grounds expanded with a second stage for the largest festival yet.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://suenosmusicfestival.com/passes/" target="_blank" ><u>Two-day festival passes starting at $329</u></a> will go on sale at noon Thursday.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/suenos-music-festival/2025/11/18/suenos-2026-fuerza-regida-headliner-lineup" >Sueños 2026 announces first headliner, and it’s genre-blending Mexican regional band Fuerza Regida</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/suenos-music-festival/2025/05/24/peso-pluma-returns-to-chicagos-suenos-festival-with-a-crowd-pleasing-set" >Peso Pluma returns to Chicago’s Sueños Festival with a crowd-pleasing set</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2025/05/25/shakira-suenos-headlines-chicago-setlist" >Shakira delivers sizzling concert at Sueños Day 1 in Chicago</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>

entries.title: $10,000 reward for arrest offered after 'senseless' deadly shooting of OEMC employee in West Ridge
entries.summary: <p>A $10,000 reward was being offered for information leading to an arrest in the deadly shooting of a much loved Office of Emergency Management and Communications employee found dead Friday morning in her West Ridge apartment. </p><p>Da'J Flowers, 36, was found inside her apartment in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/06/woman-36-slain-in-west-ridge" target="_blank" >6900 block of North Bell Avenue</a> around 9:15 a.m. with a gunshot wound to her abdomen after an OEMC director requested a well being check, Chicago police and the OEMC said.</p><p>Flowers was apparently shot several hours before that, according to a police report obtained by the Sun-Times, which said surveillance cameras captured the sound of gunshots around 7:30 p.m. Thursday. </p><p>As responding officers tried to open the unlocked door to Flowers' apartment, her body was lying in a hallway, partially blocking the door and blood was splattered on the walls and floor, according to the report. </p><p>Flowers died of multiple gunshot wounds and her death was ruled a homicide, according to the Cook County medical examiner's office, which performed an autopsy Saturday.</p><p>In one of the bedrooms, a black Ruger 9E — a 9-millimeter handgun — was found in slide lock, meaning the last bullet in the firearm had been fired, according to the police report. Multiple fired 9-millimeter casings were also recovered in the hallway. </p><p>The OEMC said Flowers was a senior administrative assistant assigned to their investigations division who joined at the beginning of the year. Flowers previously worked for the Chicago Department of Public Health. </p><p>"Da’J’s passing is a terrible loss to her family and to us here at OEMC and the City of Chicago," OEMC said in a statement. </p><p>The Cook County Crime Stoppers offer a reward up to $10,000 for any information leading to an arrest. No one was in custody as of Tuesday morning.</p><p>"Another woman has been killed in our city, and it is unacceptable,” said Paul Rutherford, Executive Director of Cook County Crime Stoppers. “This was a senseless act of violence, and someone out there knows who is responsible. We urge anyone with information, no matter how small it may seem, to come forward. Your tip could be the one that brings accountability and justice to the victim’s family.”</p><p>Anyone with information is encouraged to call 1-800-535-7867 or submit tips at <a class="Link" href="http://www.cpdtip.com/" target="_blank" >www.CPDTIP.com</a>.</p>

entries.title: Fiscales del condado desestiman los cargos contra arrestados durante protesta en instalación de ICE
entries.summary: <p>Los fiscales han retirado los cargos contra casi dos docenas de personas arrestadas durante una protesta liderada por clérigos frente a la instalación de inmigración de Broadview el otoño pasado.</p><p>El reverendo Michael Woolf, uno de los arrestados, dijo que los cargos eran “siempre atroces”.</p><p>“El hecho es que las personas que estaban allí reunidas, yo incluido, actuaban desde un punto de vista real, que lo que estaba ocurriendo en Broadview era una emergencia moral y espiritual y vimos eso pasar y nos enfrentamos a una violencia bastante intensa, y luego fuimos procesados por eso”, dijo Woolf en una entrevista.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-9b0000" name="module-9b0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>La instalación de procesamiento del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE) en el suburbio de Broadview se convirtió en un centro de protestas el otoño pasado, ya que la agresiva campaña de deportaciones del presidente Donald Trump arrasaba el área de Chicago.</p><p>En octubre, los oficiales de la policía local asumieron el control del espacio público fuera del edificio, recibiendo críticas de los manifestantes que los acusaron de ayudar a los agentes federales y de utilizar tácticas severas.</p><p>Woolf y otros miembros de la fe habían propuesto proporcionar asesoría religiosa a los detenidos en la instalación la mañana del 14 de noviembre pero se les negó la entrada al edificio.</p><p>A medida que los manifestantes se acercaban más a la instalación, con la esperanza de que los que estaban dentro escucharan sus oraciones, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2025/11/17/manifestantes-heridos-y-21-arrestados-tras-enfrentamientos-en-protesta-en-centro-de-broadview" target="_blank" >ocurrieron los enfrentamientos con la policía local, y 21 personas fueron arrestadas</a>. La oficina del Sheriff del Condado de Cook dijo que el grupo había abandonado el “área de protesta designada” y estaba “reuniéndose ilegalmente en la carretera”.</p><p>La oficina del fiscal del estado del Condado de Cook ha retirado ahora los cargos en 19 de esos casos.</p><p>“Aunque existen pruebas suficientes para respaldar esta acusación, considerando la totalidad de las circunstancias, nos negamos a proceder”, dijo la oficina del fiscal del estado del Condado de Cook en un comunicado el lunes.</p><p>“Los fiscales deben ejercer discreción en cada etapa de un caso, guiados por los intereses de justicia, equidad y el uso responsable de los recursos de la fiscalía”, se destacó.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure arrestadas por oficiales del Sheriff del Condado de Cook y enfrentaron cargos menores por obstrucción, conducta desordenada y caminar por una carretera. Estos fueron casos presentados directamente por la agencia encargada de la aplicación de la ley.</p><p>Woolf, de la Iglesia Lake Street de Evanston, comentó que no debió haber tomado tres meses desestimar los casos.</p><p>De las dos personas arrestadas ese día cuyos casos no fueron desestimados, una está acusada de disturbios y la otra está acusada de resistir a un oficial de policía.</p><p>“Continuamos orando y pensando en las personas que no han visto sus cargos retirados”, dijo Woolf. “Cualquiera que protestara en ese sitio de tortura estaba haciendo lo correcto. No creo que deban ser procesados por el estado de Illinois”.</p><p>Woolf destacó que toda la experiencia ha sido un “impactante encuentro con la violencia estatal”, y que Illinois tiene mucho trabajo por hacer para convertirse en el “líder moral que queremos ser en este país”.</p><p>Esa mañana de noviembre frente a Broadview, Woolf dijo que los oficiales lo tiraron al suelo y presionaron sus rodillas sobre él. <a class="Link" href="https://bsky.app/profile/mulchy.bsky.social/post/3m5m373kjbk26" target="_blank" >Un video muestra a Woolf de pie, tranquilamente</a>, en fila con otros manifestantes, antes de que un oficial lo agarre de la muñeca desde la multitud. Pasó siete horas bajo custodia tras su arresto.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>El reverendo Michael Woolf fue detenido en noviembre pasado durante una protesta cerca de la instalación de ICE en el suburbio oeste de Broadview.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Varias personas resultaron heridas durante el enfrentamiento ese día, incluyendo cuatro policías.</p><p>La Policía Estatal de Illinois, el Sheriff del Condado de Cook y la Policía de Broadview lanzaron un comando unificado a principios de octubre para manejar el control de multitudes en las casi diarias manifestaciones frente a la instalación de inmigración.</p><p>Las agencias de aplicación de la ley locales arrestaron al menos a 113 personas frente a la instalación entre principios de octubre y finales de noviembre.</p><p>Los manifestantes han acusado a las agencias locales de violar la Ley TRUST, que prohíbe a las fuerzas del orden de Illinois trabajar con agentes federales en la aplicación de las leyes de inmigración.</p><p>La mayoría de esos casos de arresto aún están pendientes ante la Corte del Condado de Cook.</p><p>También hubo al menos 13 personas arrestadas por agentes federales mientras protestaban frente a la instalación de Broadview el otoño pasado. Seis ya han tenido sus casos desestimados.</p><p>Los otros siete, incluido el grupo conocido como los “Broadview Six”, aún tienen casos pendientes. Los “Broadview Six” irán a juicio en mayo.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
